title: China donates table tennis equipment to Maldives Table Tennis Association (Linked to #72521)
description: On March 18th, 2019, the hand over ceremony of a newly renovated table-tennis hall took place in Malé (see project ID #72521 for further details). Alongside the ceremony, the Chinese embassy, on behalf of the Chinese Table Tennis association, donated table-tennis equipment to the Maldives Table Tennis association. The quantity and type of materials donated is unknown. According to the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the materials were donated to support the training of young Maldivian athletes.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
China donates table tennis equipment to Maldives Table Tennis Association (Linked to #72521)

# Description
On March 18th, 2019, the hand over ceremony of a newly renovated table-tennis hall took place in Malé (see project ID #72521 for further details). Alongside the ceremony, the Chinese embassy, on behalf of the Chinese Table Tennis association, donated table-tennis equipment to the Maldives Table Tennis association. The quantity and type of materials donated is unknown. According to the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the materials were donated to support the training of young Maldivian athletes.
justification: Project involves donation of sports equipment for youth development, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Table tennis equipment donation, support for young athletes training

title: China grants medicine and medical equipment to aid in the development of health services at the Hospital of Mali
description: On April 18, 2019, China granted Mali medical equipment to aid in the development of health services in the Hospital of Mali. The equipment will go to assist current efforts by the 26th Chinese medical team at the Hospital of Mali. The handover ceremony was led by Ambassador Zhu Liying, Mali's Minister of Health, doctors China had previously provided to Mali, Malian doctors, and some French medical staff. Nearly 200 people attended the ceremony. This is a part of China's continuing aid to Mali in developing their health services.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title

# Description
On April 18, 2019, China granted Mali medical equipment to aid in the development of health services in the Hospital of Mali. The equipment will go to assist current efforts by the 26th Chinese medical team at the Hospital of Mali. The handover ceremony was led by Ambassador Zhu Liying, Mali's Minister of Health, doctors China had previously provided to Mali, Malian doctors, and some French medical staff. Nearly 200 people attended the ceremony. This is a part of China's continuing aid to Mali in developing their health services.
justification: Project focuses on healthcare development without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Medical equipment grant, health services development, hospital focus

title: China donates laptops and other materials to orphans in Gao City, Mali to promote their health, education, and growth
description: In March of 2019, China donated laptops and other materials to orphans in Gao City to promote health, education, and growth. Ambassador Zhu, the Minister of Culture Diallo, the Minister of Tourism and Handicrafts Intalou, and Princess Kamatali of Burundi attended the event in which the supplies were granted.  Gao City is about 1,100 km outside of Mali's capitol of Bamako. When delivering the materials Ambassador Zhu Liying was able to see the common suburban life in Mali.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER MULTISECTOR

# Title
China donates laptops and other materials to orphans in Gao City, Mali to promote their health, education, and growth

# Description
In March of 2019, China donated laptops and other materials to orphans in Gao City to promote health, education, and growth. Ambassador Zhu, the Minister of Culture Diallo, the Minister of Tourism and Handicrafts Intalou, and Princess Kamatali of Burundi attended the event in which the supplies were granted.  Gao City is about 1,100 km outside of Mali's capitol of Bamako. When delivering the materials Ambassador Zhu Liying was able to see the common suburban life in Mali.
justification: Project focuses on social development through education and health support, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of laptops and materials to orphans, focus on health, education, and growth

title: China donates rice, flour, milk powder, green tea and other items to the Centre d’Accueil et de Placement Familial in Bamako
description: On December 24, 2019, China donated supplies, including rice, flour, milk powder, green tea, and other items to the Centre d’Accueil et de Placement Familial (CAPF) in Bamako, which is a public institution that takes in disadvantaged kids in Mali. Ambassador Zhu Liying, Minister of the Ministry of Women and Family Promotion of Mali Coulibaly, Ms. Kene, the dean of the orphanage, Zhu Yi, the chairman of Longrun Group, and Zhang Yu, the chairman of the Federation of Overseas Chinese and Chinese in Mali attended the handover ceremony.
combined_text:
# Sector
DEVELOPMENTAL FOOD AID/FOOD SECURITY ASSISTANCE

# Title
China donates rice, flour, milk powder, green tea and other items to the Centre d’Accueil et de Placement Familial in Bamako

# Description
On December 24, 2019, China donated supplies, including rice, flour, milk powder, green tea, and other items to the Centre d’Accueil et de Placement Familial (CAPF) in Bamako, which is a public institution that takes in disadvantaged kids in Mali. Ambassador Zhu Liying, Minister of the Ministry of Women and Family Promotion of Mali Coulibaly, Ms. Kene, the dean of the orphanage, Zhu Yi, the chairman of Longrun Group, and Zhang Yu, the chairman of the Federation of Overseas Chinese and Chinese in Mali attended the handover ceremony.
justification: Project involves food aid and social assistance without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of food supplies to orphanage, social welfare focus

title: Chinese Embassy donates sewing machines and other materials to the Malian Military Family Association
description: On September 20, 2019, the Chinese Embassy in Mali donated sewing machines and other materials to the Malian Military Family Association. The materials were handed over by Ambassador Zhu Liying.
staff_comments: 1. Malian Military Family Association may be mistranslated version of the organization's actual name; however, AidData has been unable to find an official name, so it has chosen this as the name. This issue merits further investigation.

title: China grants the China Government Scholarship to 58 Malian Students for the 2019-2020 school year
description: China granted the annual China Government Scholarship to Malian Students for the 2019-2020 school year. A farewell ceremony was held August 22, 2019 as 58 students prepared to leave for China. Ambassador Zhu Liying, who led the ceremony, lauded the increased number of Malian students who were being accepted into Chinese universities.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
China grants the China Government Scholarship to 58 Malian Students for the 2019-2020 school year

# Description
China granted the annual China Government Scholarship to Malian Students for the 2019-2020 school year. A farewell ceremony was held August 22, 2019 as 58 students prepared to leave for China. Ambassador Zhu Liying, who led the ceremony, lauded the increased number of Malian students who were being accepted into Chinese universities.
justification: Scholarship program for education falls under social development with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Education sector, scholarship program for students, no energy or infrastructure components

title: Chinese funds National Agricultural Development Bank of Mali Building expansion project
description: China has funded the National Agricultural Development Bank of Mali Building expansion project, in which Weihai International Economic & Technical Cooperative Co., Ltd (WIETC) will be building the new headquarters. Transaction amount is unknown. This commitment was made as a part of a group of eight contracts signed in 2019 by Chinese companies to aid in the development of infrastructure in Mali.
combined_text:
# Sector
INDUSTRY, MINING, CONSTRUCTION

# Title
Chinese funds National Agricultural Development Bank of Mali Building expansion project

# Description
China has funded the National Agricultural Development Bank of Mali Building expansion project, in which Weihai International Economic & Technical Cooperative Co., Ltd (WIETC) will be building the new headquarters. Transaction amount is unknown. This commitment was made as a part of a group of eight contracts signed in 2019 by Chinese companies to aid in the development of infrastructure in Mali.
justification: Project involves building expansion for a financial institution, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Bank building expansion, financial institution headquarters, no energy-related components mentioned

title: China Eximbank provides $106.47 million loan to Star Bulk Carriers Corp. to refinance outstanding amounts under lease agreements for three ships
description: On September 23, 2019, the Export-Import Bank of China entered into a $106.47 million USD loan facility agreement with shipping company Star Bulk Carriers Corp., which was used by Star Bulk to refinance the outstanding amounts under then-existing lease agreements of three vessels (known as Katie K, Debbie H, and Star Ayesha). The loan facility was available in three tranches of $35.49 million USD each and were repayable in 40 equal quarterly installments of $0.7 million USD and a balloon payment of $5.915 million USD payable together with the last installment. The facility was secured by (i.e. collateralized against) first priority mortgages on the three aforementioned vessels. All tranches under the facility were fully drawn down as of November 2019.
staff_comments: 1. Project_status field has been set to Completion because all Chinese financing was disbursed.
combined_text:
# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title
China Eximbank provides $106.47 million loan to Star Bulk Carriers Corp. to refinance outstanding amounts under lease agreements for three ships

# Description
On September 23, 2019, the Export-Import Bank of China entered into a $106.47 million USD loan facility agreement with shipping company Star Bulk Carriers Corp., which was used by Star Bulk to refinance the outstanding amounts under then-existing lease agreements of three vessels (known as Katie K, Debbie H, and Star Ayesha). The loan facility was available in three tranches of $35.49 million USD each and were repayable in 40 equal quarterly installments of $0.7 million USD and a balloon payment of $5.915 million USD payable together with the last installment. The facility was secured by (i.e. collateralized against) first priority mortgages on the three aforementioned vessels. All tranches under the facility were fully drawn down as of November 2019.
justification: Project involves financial refinancing of existing shipping assets without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Loan facility for refinancing existing ship leases, no mention of environmental or energy transition aspects

title: China Merchants Bank Leasing enters into sale and leaseback agreements worth $91.431 million with Star Bulk Carriers Corp. for the acquisition of Delphin Shipping' 11 dry bulk carriers (Linked to Project ID#90963)
description: In July 2019, CMB Financial Leasing Co., Ltd. (CMBF or CMBFL) entered into seven-year sale and leaseback agreements and bareboat charter party contracts worth an aggregate $91.431 million USD with Star Bulk Carriers Corp. in order to partially finance the acquisition of the 11 dry bulk carriers of Delphin Shipping, LLC, owned by private equity firm Kelso & Co. The acquisition of the Delphin vessels stemmed from a May 27, 2019 en bloc definitive agreement in which Star Bulk acquired the ships for an aggregate of 4,503,370 of its common shares (cost of shares being calculated by Star Bulk's closing share market prices on the delivery date of each vessel) and a cash consideration of $80 million USD for the total acquisition cost of $127.532 million USD. CMBF's lease financed the cash consideration portion of the acquisition. Per the terms of each bareboat charter for each vessel, Star Bulk would pay CMBL a fixed bareboat charter hire rate in quarterly installments plus interest, and Star Bulk would have the option to purchase each vessel beginning one year after each vessel's delivery to Star Bulk for a pre-determined, amortizing purchase price. Star Bulk had the obligation to purchase each vessel at the expiration of the respective bareboat term at a price ranging from $975,000 USD to $3,379,000 USD. The $91.431 million USD sale and leaseback agreements are captured via Project ID#90952.  Additionally, CMBL provided an additional aggregate value of $15,000,000 USD under the bareboat charters that Star Bulk used to finance the acquisition and installation of scrubber equipment on the Delphin vessels. This amount was to be repaid in 12 equal quarterly installments plus interest. The funds were disbursed in the second and third quarters of 2020. This financial commitment is captured via Project ID#90963.  The 628,500 deadweight-tonnage (DWT) Delphin fleet consisted of 10 56,100 DWT bulkers (Aquila, Cepheus, Columba, D. Centaurus, Dorado, Hercules, Hydrus, Leo, Pegasus, and Pyxis) and one 63,100 DWT bulker (Apus) built between 2012 and 2014 by Chinese shipbuilder Jiangsu Hantong Group Co., Ltd.; with these 11 vessels, Star Bulk's fleet grew to 120 vessels. The scrubbers were intended to allow Star Bulk to comply with the International Maritime Organization's 2020 regulations that would require shipowners to have secured exhaust gas cleaning units on all vessels. The acquisition was expected to be completed in June 2019.  Star Bulk received all 11 Delphin vessels in the third quarter of 2019. By May 2020, Star Bulk had completed its scrubber installation programme for its fleet, which now included the Delphin vessels.
staff_comments: 1. Sale and leaseback (or sale-leaseback) agreements are generally considered to be off-balance-sheet hybrid debt products. 2. Star Bulk Carriers was incorporated in 2006 and is based in Marousi, Greece.
combined_text:
# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title
China Merchants Bank Leasing enters into sale and leaseback agreements worth $91.431 million with Star Bulk Carriers Corp. for the acquisition of Delphin Shipping' 11 dry bulk carriers (Linked to Project ID#90963)

# Description
In July 2019, CMB Financial Leasing Co., Ltd. (CMBF or CMBFL) entered into seven-year sale and leaseback agreements and bareboat charter party contracts worth an aggregate $91.431 million USD with Star Bulk Carriers Corp. in order to partially finance the acquisition of the 11 dry bulk carriers of Delphin Shipping, LLC, owned by private equity firm Kelso & Co. The acquisition of the Delphin vessels stemmed from a May 27, 2019 en bloc definitive agreement in which Star Bulk acquired the ships for an aggregate of 4,503,370 of its common shares (cost of shares being calculated by Star Bulk's closing share market prices on the delivery date of each vessel) and a cash consideration of $80 million USD for the total acquisition cost of $127.532 million USD. CMBF's lease financed the cash consideration portion of the acquisition. Per the terms of each bareboat charter for each vessel, Star Bulk would pay CMBL a fixed bareboat charter hire rate in quarterly installments plus interest, and Star Bulk would have the option to purchase each vessel beginning one year after each vessel's delivery to Star Bulk for a pre-determined, amortizing purchase price. Star Bulk had the obligation to purchase each vessel at the expiration of the respective bareboat term at a price ranging from $975,000 USD to $3,379,000 USD. The $91.431 million USD sale and leaseback agreements are captured via Project ID#90952.  Additionally, CMBL provided an additional aggregate value of $15,000,000 USD under the bareboat charters that Star Bulk used to finance the acquisition and installation of scrubber equipment on the Delphin vessels. This amount was to be repaid in 12 equal quarterly installments plus interest. The funds were disbursed in the second and third quarters of 2020. This financial commitment is captured via Project ID#90963.  The 628,500 deadweight-tonnage (DWT) Delphin fleet consisted of 10 56,100 DWT bulkers (Aquila, Cepheus, Columba, D. Centaurus, Dorado, Hercules, Hydrus, Leo, Pegasus, and Pyxis) and one 63,100 DWT bulker (Apus) built between 2012 and 2014 by Chinese shipbuilder Jiangsu Hantong Group Co., Ltd.; with these 11 vessels, Star Bulk's fleet grew to 120 vessels. The scrubbers were intended to allow Star Bulk to comply with the International Maritime Organization's 2020 regulations that would require shipowners to have secured exhaust gas cleaning units on all vessels. The acquisition was expected to be completed in June 2019.  Star Bulk received all 11 Delphin vessels in the third quarter of 2019. By May 2020, Star Bulk had completed its scrubber installation programme for its fleet, which now included the Delphin vessels.
justification: Project involves financial leasing agreements for bulk carriers, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Sale and leaseback agreements for 11 dry bulk carriers, scrubber installation financing, no direct energy transition impact

title: China Merchants Bank Leasing enters into sale and leaseback agreements worth $15 million USD with Star Bulk Carriers Corp. to provide scrubbers to Delphin Shipping's 11 dry bulk carriers (Linked to Project ID#90952)
description: In July 2019, CMB Financial Leasing Co., Ltd. (CMBF or CMBFL) entered into seven-year sale and leaseback agreements and bareboat charter party contracts worth an aggregate $91.431 million USD with Star Bulk Carriers Corp. in order to partially finance the acquisition of the 11 dry bulk carriers of Delphin Shipping, LLC, owned by private equity firm Kelso & Co.  The acquisition of the Delphin vessels stemmed from a May 27, 2019 en bloc definitive agreement in which Star Bulk acquired the ships for an aggregate of 4,503,370 of its common shares (cost of shares being calculated by Star Bulk's closing share market prices on the delivery date of each vessel) and a cash consideration of $80 million USD for the total acquisition cost of $127.532 million USD. CMBF's lease financed the cash consideration portion of the acquisition.  Per the terms of each bareboat charter for each vessel, Star Bulk would pay CMBL a fixed bareboat charter hire rate in quarterly installments plus interest, and Star Bulk would have the option to purchase each vessel beginning one year after each vessel's delivery to Star Bulk for a pre-determined, amortizing purchase price. Star Bulk had the obligation to purchase each vessel at the expiration of the respective bareboat term at a price ranging from $975,000 USD to $3,379,000 USD. The $91.431 million USD sale and leaseback agreements are captured via Project ID#90952.  Additionally, CMBL provided an additional aggregate value of $15,000,000 USD under the bareboat charters that Star Bulk used to finance the acquisition and installation of scrubber equipment on the Delphin vessels. This amount was to be repaid in 12 equal quarterly installments plus interest. The funds were disbursed in the second and third quarters of 2020. This financing arrangement is captured via this project.  The 628,500 deadweight-tonnage (DWT) Delphin fleet consisted of 10 56,100 DWT bulkers (Aquila, Cepheus, Columba, D. Centaurus, Dorado, Hercules, Hydrus, Leo, Pegasus, and Pyxis) and one 63,100 DWT bulker (Apus) built between 2012 and 2014 by Chinese shipbuilder Jiangsu Hantong Group Co., Ltd.; with these 11 vessels, Star Bulk's fleet grew to 120 vessels. The scrubbers were intended to allow Star Bulk to comply with the International Maritime Organization's 2020 regulations that would require shipowners to have secured exhaust gas cleaning units on all vessels. The acquisition was expected to be completed in June 2019. Star Bulk received all 11 Delphin vessels in the third quarter of 2019. By May 2020, Star Bulk had completed its scrubber installation programme for its fleet, which now included the Delphin vessels.
staff_comments: 1. Sale and leaseback (or sale-leaseback) agreements are generally considered to be off-balance-sheet hybrid debt products.2. Star Bulk Carriers was incorporated in 2006 and is based in Marousi, Greece.3. Given that Star Bulk Carriers drew down the $15 million USD to acquire and install the scrubbers in 2020 and its fleet-wide scrubber programme was completed the same year, AidData has assumed that the scrubbers for the Delphin vessels were acquired and installed sometime in 2020, so it has coded 2020 as the actual_implementation_start_date and actual_implementation_completion_date, while also marking the actual_implementation_start_date_estimated? and actual_implementation_completion_date? fields as True.
